text: it blows my mind every day that credit cards were *ever* a thing *anywhere*, nvm that they are still basically the only viable payment method for something like 95% of all transactions in the US.  Credit cards make absolutely no sense whatsoever... instead of inventing a secure payment method, they invented a bonkers payment method and then decided to rely on an entire industry of fraud detection stuff that siphons money from all those transactions... I wonder if this started out as a scam by the credit card companies in the first place, or if the people who invented the system were simply morons and the scam grew on top of it over time

text:
For those interested in the development of the US payment system and payment choice, you may be happy to hear the Fed is trying to roll out a new instantaneous payment system called FedNow.

<@U7HAYKY9X> I may misremember things, but I think Dankort (I assume that's what you are referring to?) is only used for debit card transactions, much like the Norwegian BankAxept. I also think Dankort has a fee, just that the merchant pays a fixed fee per year depending on the # of transactions.

<@U9VG1AYSG> I don't understand why you think credit card's are so bonkers. What is your alternative? Only allow debit (including cash) transactions? Is it the "card" aspect you don't like, or the "credit"?

Moreover, your statement "basically the only viable payment method for something like 95% of all transactions in the US." is pretty far off. First, you can (almost?) always pay with debit cards when you can pay with credit cards. Second, the data shows it's wrong. Only 25% of US transactions are done by credit cards (<https://www.frbatlanta.org/banking-and-payments/consumer-payments/survey-of-consumer-payment-choice>). Third, just ask most (PhD) students who move to the US, most wait many years before they (can) get a credit card - they still survive (mostly).

That said, I fucking hate checks. So awful. I had a similar experience to <@UDB26738Q> where I get refunded by check from the US. Went to my bank, they had no idea how to cash it, and in the end they found a dusty manual in the back-back office with instructions. After 6 years in the US I still don't know how to write them, and when I bought may car I had to make the car salesman fill out the check, haha.

Edit: That was a long message. I didn't even know I was this enthusiastic about payment systems..
